s.gd: ’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn.
s.en: Thomas is the only crofter I know who rose to the status of a tycoon.

s.gd: Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach.
s.en: He did that through duty, hard work and business acumen that was unusual.

s.gd: An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd.
s.en: Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands.

s.gd: Bha seachdnar de theaghlach aige, ceathrar mhac agus triùir nighean, agus bha a h-uile fear is tè anns a’ mhalairt ach Rob.
s.en: He had seven children, four sons and three daughters, and every man and woman was in the business except for Rob.

s.gd: B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil.
s.en: Rob was the youngest and he stayed on at school.

s.gd: Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain.
s.en: When he reached the university the others wanted him to study accounting, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art.

s.gd: Dh’fhàg e an t-oilthigh agus chaidh e do sgoil ealain.
s.en: He left the university and he went to art school.

s.gd: Bha cuibhreann aige bho athair a bha tuilleadh ’s gu leòr airson fheumalachd ged a bha e dèidheil air a’ bhotal, agus cha robh e a’ dèanamh spàirn sam bith airson faighinn air adhart san t-saoghal.
s.en: He had an allowance from his father which was more than enough for his needs even though he was keen on the bottle, and he didn’t make any effort at all to get on in the world.

s.gd: Bhiodh e a’ dèanamh sgrùdadh ealain do phàipear-naidheachd agus corra dhealbh, ach bha a chaitheamh-beatha glè fhada bho ùpraid muinntir Thòmais, no ‘mafia’ Thòmais, mar a chanadh e fhèin.
s.en: He did art reviews for a newspaper and a few pictures, but his lifestyle was very far from the hubbub of Thomas’ people, or Thomas’ ‘mafia’ as he said himself.

s.gd: Nuair a dh’innis e gu robh e air nighean a thoirt a dh’fhuireach còmhla ris, thuirt Tòmas ri càch, “Tha Rob againne ron ghaoith, agus millidh aon othaisg chleimheachd an treud.”
s.en: When he mentioned that he had brought a girl to live with him, Thomas said to the rest, “Our Rob is before the wind, and one mangy lamb will destroy the flock.”

s.gd: Chuir e fios air a’ mhinistear agus thuirt e ris a dhol an sàs ann an Rob nuair a thigeadh e dhachaigh as t-samhradh.
s.en: He informed the minister and he said to him to sort out Rob when he came home in the summer.

s.gd: ’S ann an taigh Aonghais a’ Bhàillidh - caraid a bha còmhla ris san sgoil - a bhiodh Rob a’ fuireach nuair a bhiodh e aig an taigh.
s.en: It is in Angus of the Bailey’s house – a friend who was at school with him – that Rob stayed when he was home.

s.gd: Bha muinntir Thòmais air an clachan fhàgail o chionn fhada.
s.en: Thomas’ people had left the village long before.

s.gd: B’ fheudar do Aonghas an t-oilthigh fhàgail leis a’ chaitheamh - tinneas a bha cumanta aig an àm.
s.en: Angus had had to leave the university with consumption – an illness that was common at the time.

s.gd: Cha robh e a-nise comasach air obair a dhèanamh, agus seach gu robh a leithid a dh’eagal aig daoine ron tinneas a bha air, bha e glè aonaranach.
s.en: He was not able to do work now, and because of the kind of fear that people had of the illness he had, he was very lonely.

s.gd: Mar a bha nàdarrach, cha robh muinntir Thòmais airson gum biodh Rob a’ dol faisg air an euslainteach, gun luaidh air a bhith a’ cadal san aon taigh ris.
s.en: As was natural, Thomas’s people did not want Rob to be going near the patient, to say nothing of sleeping in the same house as him.

s.gd: Ach chan èisteadh Rob riutha, agus ’s ann an taigh Aonghais a chaidh an t-Urramach a bhruidhinn ris.
s.en: But Ron would not listen to them, and it is in Angus’ house that the Reverend went to talk to him.

s.gd: Loisg e a’ chiad urchair anns a’ bhad.
s.en: He fired the first shot straight away.

s.gd: “A bheil thu a’ tuigsinn gu bheil thu dol a’ bhàsachadh?” ars esan.
s.en: “Do you understand that you are going to die?” he said.

s.gd: “Tha gu dearbh,” arsa Rob, le gàire, “ach ’s e an rud mu dheireadh a tha dùil a’m a dhèanamh.”
s.en: “Yes of course,” said Rob, with a smile, “but it’s the last thing I am expecting to do.”

s.gd: Cha robh fiù fiamh a’ ghàire air aghaidh mhòir, bhrògaich an Urramaich.
s.en: There wasn’t even the hint of a smile on the Reverend’s big sturdy face.

s.gd: Cha robh e cleachdte ri còmhradh faoin.
s.en: He was not accustomed to silly conversation.

s.gd: Thòisich e a’ faighneachd an robh fios aig Rob gu robh siud is seo anns a’ Bhìoball, agus thòisich Rob ag innse dha rudan eile a tha anns a’ Bhìoball.
s.en: He started asking whether Rob knew this and that in the Bible, and Rob started telling him other things that are in the Bible.

s.gd: “Nach tuirt Dia ris an nathair, ‘Air do bhroinn imichidh tu’.
s.en: “Didn’t God say to the snake, ‘You shall move on your stomach’.

s.gd: Dè mar a bha i ag imeachd roimhe?
s.en: How had she moved before that?

s.gd: Na leugh thu Lebhiticus XX:21 agus Deuteronomi XXV:5?
s.en: Did you read Leviticus XX:21 and Deuteronmy XXB:5?

s.gd: Nach eil iad calg-dhìreach an aghaidh a chèile?
s.en: Are they not diametrically opposed to each other?

s.gd: Na mhothaich thu gu bheil naoi dhe na h-àithntean àicheanach?
s.en: Did you realise that nine of the commandments are negative?

s.gd: Chan eil iad ag iarraidh ort càil fialaidh no feumail a dhèanamh.
s.en: They don’t ask you to do anything generous or useful.

s.gd: Tha thusa a’ taghadh a h-uile ceann-teagaisg a tha toirt taic dhan t-saobh-chràbhadh agad fhèin.”
s.en: You are selecting all the lessons that support your own superstition.

s.gd: Tha argamaid dhen t-seòrsa seo a’ dèanamh gu leòr de theas ach glè bheag de sholas, agus mu dheireadh dh’èirich am ministear, aghaidh dearg feargach, agus chrath e a làmhan.
s.en: An argument of this sort makes plenty of heat but very little light, and at last the minister rose, face red and angry, and he shook his hands.

s.gd: “Imich air mo chùlaibh, a Shàtain,” ars esan.
s.en: “Move behind me, Satan,” he said.

s.gd: Bha Rob a’ gàireachdainn, agus dh’èigh e às a dhèidh: “Leugh na Britheamhan 1-19.”
s.en: Rob was laughing, and he shouted after him: “Read the Judges 1–19.”

s.gd: Nuair a dh’fhalbh am ministear thug Aonghas a-mach am botal.
s.en: When the minister left, Angus brought out the bottle.

s.gd: “Faodaidh sinn comanachadh a-nis,” ars esan.
s.en: “We can now take communion,” he said.

s.gd: Chaidh am ministear gu oifis Thòmais anns a’ bhaile mhòr agus thuirt e gu robh Rob caillte.
s.en: The minister went to Thomas’ office in the city and he said that Rob was lost.

s.gd: “Tha thu a’ toirt cuibhreann do neo-dhiadhaire,” ars esan, “agus nan sguireadh tu a phàigheadh sin, thigeadh e gu chiall.”
s.en: “You are giving an allowance to an atheist,” he said, “and if you were to stop paying that, he would come to his senses.”

s.gd: “No chailleadh e am beagan a tha aige,” arsa Tòmas.
s.en: “Or he would lose the little that he has,” said Thomas.

s.gd: “Nach fhaodadh e a dhol na thramp.
s.en: “Would that he not become a tramp.

s.gd: Tha e na mhasladh gu leòr dhuinn mar a tha.”
s.en: He is enough of an embarrassment to us as it is.”

s.gd: Bha Tòmas na èildear ann an Eaglais Shaor Alba agus bha e duilich dha leithid Roib a thuigsinn.
s.en: Thomas was an elder in the Free Church of Scotland and it was hard for him to understand the likes of Rob.

s.gd: ’S ann air ealain a bha Rob agus Aonghas a’ bruidhinn.
s.en: It was about art that Rob and Angus were speaking.

s.gd: ’S e fear-ealain a bh’ ann an Aonghas, agus o chionn fhada a-nis bha Rob a’ reic a h-uile dealbh a dhèanadh e.
s.en: Angus was an artist, and for a while now Rob had been selling all the pictures he would make.

s.gd: Thàinig piseach air a shlàinte bho dh’fhàs e sealbhach agus o chionn ghoirid bha e air obair fhaighinn ann an oifis fir-lagha anns a’ bhaile mhòr.
s.en: Improvement came to his health since he became fortunate and recently he had got a job in a lawyers’ office in the city.

s.gd: ’S ann airson seo a bha an dà charaid cho subhach.
s.en: That was why the two friends were so cheerful.

s.gd: Nuair a chaidh Rob a chèilidh air an teaghlach bha iad mar a b’ àbhaist ag innse dha cho amaideach ’s a bha a chaitheamh-beatha, ach bha a pheathraichean airson cluinntinn mu dheidhinn na h-ìghne a bha a’ fuireach còmhla ris.
s.en: When Ron went to visit the family they told him as usual how foolish his lifestyle was, but his sisters wanted to hear about the girl who was living with him.

s.gd: Nuair a sheall e a dealbh dhaibh, thuirt tè: “Dhia beannaich mi, ’s e Sìonach a tha seo.”
s.en: When he showed them her picture, one said: “God bless me, this is a Chinese.”

s.gd: Thuirt tè eile: “Tha i brèagha ach dè tha i a’ dèanamh?”
s.en: Another one said: “She is beautiful but what does she do?”

s.gd: Nuair a dh’innis e gur e sgalag ann an taigh-òsta a bha innte, thuirt an treas tè: “’S cinnteach nach eil thu dol a phòsadh a’ chreutair.”
s.en: When he mentioned that she was a servant in a hotel, the third one said: “Surekly you won’t be going to marry the creature.”

s.gd: “Carson?” arsa Rob.
s.en: “Why?” said Rob.

s.gd: “Nach e sgalag a bha nam mhàthair mus do phòs i?”
s.en: “Wasn’t my mother a servant before she married?”

s.gd: Cha do dh’fhaighnich a phàrantan mu deidhinn idir, ach gheàrr iad a chuibhreann agus cha b’ fhada gus an robh e bochd.
s.en: His parents did not ask about her at all, but they cut his allowance and it was not long until he was poor.

s.gd: Anns a’ gheamhradh bhris a shlàinte, ach lean e air a’ reic dealbhan Aonghais gus an deach a thoirt dhan ospadal.
s.en: In the winter his health broke, but he continued selling Angus’ pictures until he was taken to the hospital.

s.gd: Nuair a thàinig fios bhon nighinn a bha còmhla ris gun bhàsaich e, cha b’ urrainn duine de mhuinntir Thòmais am malairt fhàgail, agus dh’iarr iad ormsa a dhol a Lunnainn a choimhead às dèidh ghnothaichean.
s.en: When news came from the girl who was with him that he had died, none of Thomas’ people could leave the business, and they asked me to go to London to look after things.

s.gd: Bha lobht aig Rob faisg air Sloan Square, agus sin far na choinnich mi ri nighean Roib - Lai Po Kan.
Sheall i dhomh clòsaid mhòr làn de dheilbh: na deilbh a rinn Aonghas.
s.en: She showed me a large closet full of pictures: the pictures that Angus had made.

s.gd: “Bha fios aig Rob,” ars ise, “nach eil tàlant ealain idir aig a charaid, ach cha robh e airson a ghoirteachadh.”
s.en: “Rob knew,” she said, “that his friend had no artistic talent whatsoever, but he did not want to hurt him.”

s.gd: ’S ann dhan chladh againn fhìn a chuir sinn Rob, agus aig an adhlacadh dh’innis mi do Aonghas gu faca mi mòran dhen obair aige ann an lobhta Roib.
s.en: It was to our own cemetary that we sent Rob, and at the funeral I told Angus that I had seen a lot of his work in Rob’s loft.

s.gd: “Bha amharas agam air sin,” ars esan.
s.en: “I suspected that,” he said.

s.gd: “Fhuair e na deilbh sin gu ìre bhig an-asgaidh agus bha e gan tasgadh an sin airson fortan a dhèanamh asta.
s.en: “He got those pictures almost for free and he was storing them there to make a fortune from them.

s.gd: Bha e dìreach mar càch.
s.en: He was just like the others.

s.gd: Cha robh càil air aire duine aca a-riamh ach airgead.”
s.en: There was nothing on their minds ever but money.“

s.gd: Nuair a bha sinn a’ dealachadh dh’fhaighnich Aonghas: “Dè thug bàs dha?”
s.en: When we were parting Angus asked: “What killed him?”

s.gd: “A’ chaitheamh,” arsa mise, agus smaoinich mi air earrann a tha sa Bhìoball a tha ag ràdh rudeigin mar ‘Gràdh as mò na seo chan eil aig neach air bith’ - ach cha tuirt mi lide.
s.en: Consumption, I said, and I thought about the verse that is in the Bible that says something like ‘Greater grace than this has no man’ – but I said nothing.
